0.name: Epistemology
0.definition: The theory of knowledge, especially with regard to its methods, validity, and scope, and the distinction between justified belief and opinion

0.name: Rationalism
0.definition: On rationalist epistemological approaches

0.name: Positivism
0.definition: On their being definite, knowable truths or facts, which are verifiable

1.name: Post-Positivism
1.definition: On their being definite, knowable truths or facts, which are considered true until falsified

1.name: Skepticism
1.definition: On skepticial epistemological approaches

0.name: Empiricism
0.definition: Wherein truth is defined probabilistically based on sensory (or sensory derived) evidence

1.name: Anti-Positivism
1.definition: Wherein definite truth is unknowable and all definitions are considered constructed by the definer

1.name: Teleology
1.definition: On the explanation of phenomena in terms of the purpose they serve rather than of the cause by which they arise.

0.name: Explanatory
0.definition: To explain the causes or circumstance of an event or process

0.name: Descriptive
0.definition: To recreate or simulate past events 'as they really were'

1.name: Predictive
1.definition: To use history as a means of developing models for predicting events or processes in the future

1.name: Memorial
1.definition: To encourage or support the remembrance of an event or process

0.name: Moral
0.definition: On the practice of judging the morality of historical actions

0.name: Justice
0.definition: To use history as a form of honouring or condemning specific individuals or groups

0.name: Heroes
0.definition: To use history to honour or make exemplars of heroes of an event or process

1.name: Villains
1.definition: To use history to condemn or punish villians

1.name: Example
1.definition: On using history to provide moral (or immoral) examples

0.name: Virtue
0.definition: On providing virtuous examples to follow

1.name: Vice
1.definition: On providing examples of vice to avoid

1.name: Amoral
1.definition: On memorials without a morality component

0.name: Archival
0.definition: To approach a historical project in order to fill gaps or complete narratives

1.name: Allusion
1.definition: To use history as a common cultural touchstone in order to illustrate wider truths

2.name: Methodology
2.definition: The methods by which History is practiced

0.name: Material Historicism
0.definition: A framework which focuses on the material conditions of the past as well as productive roles and relations

1.name: Feminist Historiography
1.definition: A framework which focuses on gender (biological or social) identity and relations in the past

2.name: Histoire des Mentalités
2.definition: A framework which focuses on the ways in which people of a given time period thought about, interacted with, and classified the world around them

3.name: Liberalism (IR)
3.definition: A theory which accepts multiple types of actors in a system that can include mutually benefitial cooperation

4.name: Realism (IR)
4.definition: A theory which declares states to be the actors in an anarchic system based on self-interest

0.name: Archival
0.definition: After Observation; On using archival material

1.name: Survey
1.definition: After Experimentation; On using survey or other actively collected material

0.name: Close Reading
0.definition: The meticulous reading of a text for vocabulary choices, internal structures, and external references

0.name: Probabilistic
0.definition: On the process of discerning trends or patterns from large quantities of quantitative data

1.name: Presentation
1.definition: The process by which history is written

0.name: Scope
0.definition: On the scope, geographically, chronologically or sociologically of history

0.name: Case Study
0.definition: On a small geographical, chronological or sociological segment of history

0.name: Comparative History
0.definition: On comparing two or more case studies on a common chronological, geographical and sociological segment of history

1.name: Single
1.definition: On a single case studies on a specific chronological, geographical and sociological segment of history

0.name: Chronological
0.definition: On a small chronological segment of history

0.name: Chronological
0.definition: On a small chronological segment of history

1.name: Geographical
1.definition: On a small geographical segment of history

1.name: Sociological
1.definition: On a small sociological segment (group) of history

1.name: Long Duree
1.definition: On a long geographical, chronological or sociological segment of history

1.name: Sociological
1.definition: On the history of races or long duree civilisations

0.name: Modelling
0.definition: On the practice of developing general models from disparate sets of data

1.name: Narrative
1.definition: On the practice of using a stylized or streamlined narrative

1.name: Counter Argument
1.definition: On the practice of negating or falsifying an alternative narrative

0.name: Ethos
0.definition: On the authority of the speaker

1.name: Pathos
1.definition: On the emotions aroused in the reader

0.name: Deduction
0.definition: Reasoning from a priori or analytic truths

1.name: Inferential
1.definition: Infering premises from empirical evidence

0.name: Induction
0.definition: Infering premises from empirical evidence

2.name: Abduction
2.definition: Accepting a wider premise as probable in order to consider minor premises and conclusions

0.name: Critical Analysis
0.definition: On the practice of writing critical anlayses of historical evidence

1.name: Judgement
1.definition: On that general sense of "historical judgement" employed by historians in selecting evidence, cause and effect chains, and relevancy

0.name: Selection
0.definition: On the choice of evidence from a selection of possible options

1.name: Definitions
1.definition: On the practice of providing discplinary (rather than lexographic) definitions

1.name: Breadth
1.definition: On the practice of providing multiple evidence sources when making a claim

0.name: Correlation
0.definition: On the process of ascribing or pin-pointing events in time

1.name: Ordering
1.definition: On the orderng of events in sequence

1.name: Causal
1.definition: On the practice of determining and illustrating cause and effect

1.name: Cause
1.definition: On the description of causation

0.name: Action
0.definition: On the ascription of motives to actions

1.name: Expectations
1.definition: On people acting based on inferred motives or forthcoming actions of others

1.name: Intrinsic
1.definition: On explaining causes through intrinsic character traits

3.name: Ontology
3.definition: On the set of concepts and categories in a subject area or domain that shows their properties and the relations between them.

0.name: Conceptual
0.definition: On the categorisation and mapping of relationships between concepts

0.name: Evidence
0.definition: On the categorisation and mapping of relationships between concepts of evidence

0.name: Records
0.definition: On the nature and interpretation of documents and other historical records

0.name: Direct
0.definition: On those materials deemed immediately connected with the phenomena they describe

1.name: Impressions
1.definition: Non-testimony based marks, impression, or evidence of action

0.name: Myth
0.definition: On those materials deemed to be distilled or thematic narratives, rather than literal accounts

1.name: Indirect
1.definition: On the concept of records that are indirect or removed from what they record

0.name: Secondary Evidence
0.definition: On those materials deemed to be analysis or critical comment, based upon primary material

1.name: Tertiary Evidence
1.definition: On those materials deemed to be meta-analysis or narrative forming, based upon primary and secondmary material

0.name: A Priori
0.definition: Generalisations / Knowledge so imbedded in human experience they are pre-cultural

1.name: Cultural
1.definition: Generalisations that are culture-dependent

1.name: Analysis
1.definition: On the categorisation and mapping of relationships between analytical concepts

0.name: Property
0.definition: On the categorisation of analytical concepts (core categories)

0.name: Event
0.definition: On the analytical concept of a discrete event

1.name: Process
1.definition: On the analytical concept of a process (an ongoing event)

1.name: Attribute
1.definition: On attaching specific attributes to analytical concepts (differientation)

0.name: Domain
0.definition: The fields, discplines or other scholarly domains which differientate the purpose of the analysis

0.name: Natural Philosophy
0.definition: On the study of the natural world

3.name: Natural History
3.definition: On the discipline of Natural History as distinct from other disciplines

1.name: Moral Philosophy
1.definition: On the study of the conceptual world

0.name: Ethnography
0.definition: On the discipline of Ethnography as distinct from other disciplines

1.name: History
1.definition: On the discipline of History as distinct from other disciplines

2.name: Philosophy
2.definition: On the discipline of Philosophy as distinct from other disciplines

3.name: Political Science
3.definition: On the discipline of Political Science as distinct from other disciplines

4.name: International Relations
4.definition: On the discipline of International Relations as distinct from other disciplines

1.name: Range
1.definition: The categories or descriptions attributed to analytical concepts during differientation

0.name: Modern History
0.definition: History that occurs after 1500 A.D.

0.name: Late Modern History
0.definition: History that occurs after 1800 A.D.

0.name: Long Nineteenth Century
0.definition: History that occurs between c1800 A.D. and c1900

1.name: Long Twentieth Century
1.definition: History that occures between c1900 A.D. and the present

0.name: Non-Contemporary History
0.definition: History that occurred in the 20th century but not at the time of writing

1.name: Contemporary History
1.definition: History that is contemporaneous with the historian (20th Century)

1.name: Early Modern History
1.definition: History between 1500 and 1800 A.D.

1.name: Pre-Modern History
1.definition: History before 1500 A.D.

0.name: Pre-Medieval History
0.definition: History before fuedal or medieval period

0.name: Recorded History
0.definition: History since writing, before the fuedal period

0.name: Classical History
0.definition: History of the Classical world

1.name: Ancient History
1.definition: History of the Ancient World

1.name: Before Recorded History
1.definition: History before the advent of writing

1.name: Medieval History
1.definition: History of the fuedal or medieval period

0.name: Land
0.definition: Defined by land

1.name: Water
1.definition: Defined by Water

0.name: Nationality
0.definition: On the causes or effects of grouping by nationality

1.name: Ethnic Groups
1.definition: On the causes or effects of grouping by common culture, language or origin

1.name: Physical
1.definition: On the categorisation and mapping of relationships between physical manifestations (items and behaviours)

0.name: Environment
0.definition: On the categorisation and mapping of relationships between environmental factors (non-human)

0.name: Fixed
0.definition: On (practically) fixed elements of the environment, such as geographical features

0.name: Geography
0.definition: On the geographical record

1.name: Temporary
1.definition: On (practically) temporary elements of the environment, such as weather events or disastors

1.name: Human
1.definition: On the categorisation and mapping of relationships between manifestations of human agency

0.name: Behaviour
0.definition: On the manifestations of human behaviour

0.name: Customs
0.definition: On long-term cultural habits and customs

1.name: Individual Actions
1.definition: On the individualised actions of persons, rather than general customs or habits of peoples

1.name: Artefacts
1.definition: On the physcial remains of human agency; artefacts and manipulated objects

0.name: Object
0.definition: On physical objects without (or not concerned with) human markingsdenoting language

0.name: Fixed
0.definition: On fixed or practically immovable objects of human creation

0.name: Architecture
0.definition: On the built environment

1.name: Movable
1.definition: On practically movable objects of human creation

1.name: Mark
1.definition: On human markings, whether phoentic language or other communication

0.name: Image
0.definition: On images of human creation

0.name: Designed
0.definition: On images of human creation that are primarily created from intervening design rather than procedural capture (drawing/carving)

1.name: Captured
1.definition: On images of human creation that are primarily created from procedural capture rather than intervening design (video / photography)

1.name: Text
1.definition: On texts (loosely defined) of human creation; marks that convey literal or direct information

0.name: Oral
0.definition: Information originally or intended to be conveyed orally (including written records of them)

0.name: Speeches
0.definition: On records of prepared human speech

1.name: Rumours
1.definition: On rumours or folk histories

1.name: Written
1.definition: Information originally or intended to be conveyed in written form
